Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract:
PI: Ju, Tao (0846072)
CAREER: Reconstructing Geometrically and Topologically Correct Models


Bio-medical imaging and 3D scanning are widely used for acquiring realistic digital models of real-world objects, from those that are around us, like coffee mugs and statues, to those within us, like proteins and organs. In many applications, polygonal surfaces need to be reconstructed from the data captured by scanning or imaging. Besides visualization, these polygonal models have wide uses in computation and manufacturing, where geometrically and topologically correct models are required. However, as the input data is often noisy or incomplete, it is still difficult in practice to obtain correct polygonal surfaces using existing reconstruction algorithms. The reconstructed surface may exhibit geometric inconsistencies including gaps, holes and intersections, and more often, topological artifacts such as handles and disconnections. Furthermore, most reconstruction algorithms that promise geometrically correct outputs are designed for closed surfaces with well-defined inside and outside, and hence not applicable to surfaces that contain intended open boundaries or interior membranes. These more general surfaces are commonly used in CAD as well as bio-medical modeling.

This research is developing robust polygonal surface reconstruction algorithms that offer guarantees for geometric and topological correctness. To achieve this goal, an integrated framework is developed that combines and extends existing surface reconstruction and model repair algorithms to produce correct polygonal models that best represent the input data, in the form of either 3D point clouds or grayscale volumes. The research is also exploring new reconstruction and repair algorithms for open and non-manifold surfaces, thereby extending the correctness guarantees to a much larger class of models than those can be handled by existing methods.

POR.DRECONTENT:
3D scanning and imaging are widely used for acquiring realistic digital models of real-world objects. In many applications, polygonal surfaces need to be reconstructed from the scanned or imaged data. Besides visualization, polygonal models are commonly used in computing and manufacturing, particularly for animation, physical simulations, rapid-prorotyping, and 3D printing. Many of these applications require the models to meet certain correctness criteria. Such criteria could be geometric, such as being free of haps, holes, and intersections, or topological, such as having a specified number of connected components and topological handles. Due to the presence of noise and incompleteness in typical scanned or imaged data, obtaining correct reconstructions becomes a particularly challenging problem.

 

Existing reconstruction paradigms usually proceed in two phases, reconstruction and repair, in which the errors produced by the first phase is identified and resolved in the second phase. However, the repair phase usually ignore the raw data that was used for the reconstruction phase, resulting in models that do not faithfully represent the input data. In addition, most current reconstruction methods are designed for closed, manifold models (e.g., those that bound a solid piece of volume). Yet open, non-manifold surfaces are often useful for specific applications.

 

In this project, we have developed a series of novel algorithms for correctly reconstructing polygonal surfaces that address these deficiencies of existing approaches. Unlike the existing two-phase paradigm, our reconstruction algorithms incorporate correctness criteria as constraints so that the output does not need to be repaired. Also, we have investigated algorithms for creating open and non-manifold surface creation with guaranteed topological and/or geometric correctness. Some of the notable outcomes are:

 

  • We developed the first algorithms for topologically-correct surfacing of spatial curves. Such curves could arise from creative design or interactive segmentation of medical volumes. The output of the algorithms guarantee that the surfaces are geometrically correct and obey the desired topological properties, such as being manifold, conforming to desired degree of non-manifoldness, or having a user-specified number of topological handles.

 

  • We developed the first algorithms for polygonizing open curves and surfaces that have an implicit definition. These curves and surfaces can represent a variety of features in scalar field, vector field, and tensor field. Our algorithms ensure that the polygonized geometry faithfully capture the geometry and topology of the continuous definitions.

 

  • We developed certified algorithms in more general reconstruction problems. In particular, we explored the creation of vector fields on surfaces that obey a given topological skeleton, and the design of pop-up paper structure that can be physically realized.

 

As mentioned above, reconstructing correct polygonal surfaces has wide application in engineering, manufacturing, and bio-medicine. The increased availability of correct models, as a result of the project, will help to increase both efficiency and accuracy in these applications, which will in turn have substantial impact on the society as a whole.
